H0.text: Interfering with the water cycle is how the nitrogen compounds, produced by excessive use of nitrogen‑based fertilizers and runoff that increases the nitrogen content of lakes and bays, directly affect aquatic ecosystems.

H1.text: Decreasing the predator population is the direct effect on aquatic ecosystems caused by nitrogen compounds that accumulate in lakes and bays due to runoff from excessive use of nitrogen‑based fertilizers.

H2.text: Increasing the rate of algae growth is the direct effect of nitrogen compounds on aquatic ecosystems when excessive use of nitrogen‑based fertilizers causes runoff that raises nitrogen content in lakes and bays.

H3.text: Causing aquatic animals to grow larger is the direct effect of nitrogen compounds on aquatic ecosystems when excessive nitrogen‑based fertilizer use causes runoff that increases the nitrogen content of lakes and bays.

A4.text: Phosphorus and nitrogen are the two main nutrients that cause cultural eutrophication as they enrich the water, allowing for some aquatic plants, especially algae to grow rapidly and bloom in high densities.
